Award.AbstractNarration:
Solutions to many problems in graph theory and extremal combinatorics require structural information of graphs and hypergraphs. The PI plans to study graph structures and their potential applications to graph colorings, in particular, a long standing conjecture of Seymour on topological K5. He also plans to work on several problems of Bollobas and Scott about partitions of graphs and hypergraphs. The PI has previously obtained a number of results in the proposed area using structural and extremal methods, and he plans to continue his work.

Graph theory studies discrete structures such as networks (e.g., the Internet). Many problems in the real world may be formulated as problems on graphs, and mathematical techniques have been applied to attack such problems. When the structure of a class of graphs is well understood, efficient methods can often be found to solve problems on these graphs. When the structure is not clear, one often tries other mathematical methods (e.g. algebraic and probabilistic methods). This proposal considers both structural and extremal problems in graph theory. Progress on these problems should increase our understanding of graph theory and has potential applications to areas such as optimization and computer science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solutions to many problems in graph theory and extremal combinatorics require structural information of graphs and hypergraphs involved.

The PI investigated  graph structures and their potential applications to graph coloring. The main goal was to make progress on 
a long standing conjecture of Kelmans and Seymour on subdivisions of the complete graph on five vertices,  which is related to the famous Four Color Theorem.  The PI also  worked on several problems where one wants to find partitions of graphs that satisfy several constraints simultaneously. Such problems are natural and could have real applications. 

Together with graduate students Dawei He and Yan Wang,  the PI solved  the long-standing Kelmans-Seymour conjecture mentioned above.
The PI has also solved several problems of Bollobas and Scott on graph partitions. This project has resulted in a number of publications, listed below. 






 J. Ma and X. Yu, K5-Subdivisions in graphs containing K4-, Journal Combinatorial Theory, Series B, Vol. 103, (2013), 713--732.

 B. Xu and X. Yu, On judicious bisections of graphs, Journal of Combinatorial Theory, Series B, Vol. 106,  (2014), 30--69.

Y. Hong, L. Kang, and X. Yu, Non-separating cycles avoiding specific vertices, Journal of Graph Theory, Vol. 80, (2015), 253--267.

 K. Kawarabayashi, J. Ma, and X. Yu, Subdivisions of K5 in graphs containing K{2,3}, Journal of  Combinatorial Theory, Series B, Vol. 113, (2015), 18--67. 

 J. Ma and X. Yu, On judicious bipartitions of graphs,  Combinatorica, Vol. 36, (2016),   537--556.

 J. Ma, Q. Xie, and X. Yu, Graphs containing topological H,  Journal of  Graph Theory, Vol. 82, (2016),  121--153.

  Y. Sun and X. Yu, On a coloring conjecture of Hajos,  Graphs and Combinatorics, Vol. 32, (2016),  351--361. 

Y. Wang, Q. Xie, and X. Yu,  Induced forests in bipartite planar graphs,  Journal of Combinatorics, Vol. 8, (2017), 93--166.

D. He, Y. Wang, and X. Yu, The Kelmans-Seymour conjecture I; special separations, arXiv:1511.05020 [math.CO].

D. He, Y. Wang, and X. Yu,  The Kelmans-Seymour conjecture II; 2-vertices in $K_4^-$, arXiv:1602.07557 [math.CO].

 D. He, Y. Wang, and X. Yu,  The Kelmans-Seymour conjecture III; 3-vertices in $K_4^-$, arXiv:1609.05747 [math.CO].

 D. He, Y. Wang, and X. Yu,  The Kelmans-Seymour conjecture IV; a proof, arXiv:1612.07189 [math.CO].
